history.content: DATASCI W207,  IND ENG C227A,  IND ENG 242

children.subject:
As indicated by the lists above, Berkeley has plenty of ML courses.

I don't see anyone in this thread suggesting grad school, but it's certainly a good idea if ML is what you want to study.

A lot of machine learning is in some intersection of statistical techniques and optimization - specifically convex optimization (notable exceptions include deep learning). 

Many courses, as listed above, don't explicitly have "machine" or "learning" in its title but are very much so "advanced ML concepts".
Convex optimization is an integral part of machine learning.

W207 is the same as 189.

C227A and 242 aren't ML - Convex Optimization and Data Science.

Am I wrong? I want to learn more advanced ML concepts, not just ML classes which cover the same material.

And grad school isn't the solution: Because if Berkeley, the top CS school in the US, offers only 1 ML class, how can I expect other grad schools to offer more?

history.content:
VS 265 - neural computation - focus on neural networks, only offered every 2 years or so (fall of even-numbered years usually).

Stat 215A - applied statistical models, offered every fall

CS 280 - computer vision

CS 281A/B - statistical learning theory

CS 287 - advanced robotics

CS 288 - statistical NLP, not offered regularly

CS 294 - scalable machine learning

Stat 243 - statistical computing

Stat 212B - topics in deep learning, not offered regularly

Also, a number of special topics courses in the Info school, as well as many courses in the Data Science department.

VS 265 - neural computation - focus on neural networks, only offered every 2 years or so (fall of even-numbered years usually).

Stat 215A - applied statistical models, offered every fall

CS 280 - computer vision

CS 281A/B - statistical learning theory

CS 287 - advanced robotics

CS 288 - statistical NLP, not offered regularly

CS 294 - scalable machine learning

Stat 243 - statistical computing

Stat 212B - topics in deep learning, not offered regularly

It seems like Berkeley has very few ML courses. Is this true?

Stat 154/CS 189 - Machine Learning

CS 294-112 - Deep Reinforcement Learning

Any other ML courses?
history.subject: Machine Learning courses
